messageBody:

What you are doing sounds like acceptance testing. Unit testing with JUnit
is intended to QUICKLY show that all tests pass while you are refactoring,
or that only one test fails when you are writing test-first code.

Acceptance testing usually tests that the application satisfies the user's
Stories... failures are allowed (and expected) for un-implemented stories.
Kent Beck describes the results of Acceptance testing to be a number like
"89% of tests pass".

as someone else has said:

>I use JUnit for application-level acceptance testing of web applications
>(using HttpUnit - see http://httpunit.sourceforge.net) as well as just unit
>testing, and having something like this I would find extremely useful.
>
>For example, I could then do something like:
>
> Page loginPage = getLoginPage();
> check(loginPage.existenceOfFeature1()); // important, but not fatal
> check(loginPage.existenceOfFeature2()); // important, but not fatal
> assert(loginPage.existenceOfFeature3()); // fatal, cannot procede if
fails

You can extend JUnit to define "check" to increment the number of passes or
failures without throwing the exception that "assert" throws.
